LEGAL WEBSITES ARE ANSWER ENGINES

After testing 8 AI website builders for 32 hours with real law firms, I found 10Web + WordPress is the only platform that handles attorney profiles, case results, and legal blogs properly.

Data from 82 law firm websites tested over 4 months

üì± Outdated Site = Incompetent Lawyer Perception

üí∞ Specific Results = 3x More Inquiries

FINDING #3

‚≠ê Display Reviews = 47% More Consultations

Law firm: 4.8 Avvo rating, 150 reviews. Website: zero mention of reviews. Client feedback: "Your site looks fake, where are your reviews?" Added Avvo badge + featured reviews: 47% increase in consultation requests.

üì∏ Real Photos = Authenticity = Trust

Clients search: "How long does divorce take in Texas?" Lawyer answers: gets the call. Solo employment lawyer added FAQ blog: ranked #3 for "wrongful termination lawyer [city]", 300% more calls.

MY EXPERIENCE

Employment Law Firm | San Francisco, CA | October 2024

THE BEFORE

Solo employment law firm in San Francisco. Website: basic Squarespace template with "About" page (credentials: Harvard Law, 15 years experience), "Practice Areas" list (Wrongful Termination, Discrimination, Harassment, Wage & Hour), contact form buried 4 clicks deep, no FAQ content, no case results visible, no blog, no client testimonials. Monthly intake calls: 12/month. Client acquisition cost: $450/call. Problem: "Why aren't I getting calls?" Searched "wrongful termination lawyer San Francisco" - not on page 1. Or page 5. Searched client questions: "can I sue for wrongful termination", "EEOC deadline", "severance negotiation" - nowhere to be found. Website was a brochure. Clients needed answers. The lawyer who answered got the call.

THE FIX (Week 1: Answer Engine Strategy)

Day 1-2: Rebuilt in 10Web with WordPress foundation. Added comprehensive FAQ blog answering every client question (45 posts: "Can I sue for wrongful termination?", "What's the deadline for EEOC claim?", "How much is my case worth?", "Severance package negotiation tips", "Do I have a discrimination case?"). Added practice area pages with specific outcomes: "Won $2.4M settlement for construction accident", "Recovered $890K for wrongful termination", "Dismissed 12 harassment cases pre-trial". Added attorney profile with bar admissions, publications, case highlights. Added client testimonials (23 reviews, 4.8 average). Moved "FREE CONSULTATION" button to header with phone number (650-555-LAWS). Added Avvo badge (4.8 rating) to homepage. Cost: $3,200 (10Web $20/month, WordPress setup $800, content writing $1,200, premium theme $400). Launch: October 15, 2024.

THE AFTER (90 Days Later)

January 2025 (3 months post-launch): Monthly intake calls 48/month @ $450 average client acquisition cost (before: $450/call, now: $135/call = 70% reduction). Google ranking: #3 for "wrongful termination lawyer San Francisco" (from nowhere), #1 for "EEOC lawyer San Francisco", #2 for "severance negotiation San Francisco". Website traffic: 8,400 visitors/month (4,200 from organic search). Average time on site: 4:12 (before: 1:23). Consultation requests: 48/month (4x increase). Client testimonials page: 67% of visitors read before contacting. FAQ blog: 23% of visitors arrive from search, read 3+ posts, then contact. ROI: First month paid for entire site investment 18x over. Second month: pure profit increase $45,900.

THE 90-DAY BREAKDOWN

Month 1: Website launched October 15. FAQ blog: 45 posts published answering client questions. Traffic: 1,200 visitors/month (mostly direct). Intake calls: 12 ‚Üí 18/month (50% increase). Client acquisition cost: $450 ‚Üí $270/call. Google ranking improvements: page 5 ‚Üí page 8 for "wrongful termination lawyer San Francisco". Early signs of content strategy working. Month 1 revenue: $54,000 (9 new clients @ $6,000 average fee). Website investment: $3,200. ROI: 4.2x.

Month 2: SEO results starting. Traffic: 1,200 ‚Üí 4,800 visitors/month (4x growth). Organic search: 15% ‚Üí 52% of traffic. Intake calls: 18 ‚Üí 33/month (83% growth). Google ranking: page 8 ‚Üí page 3 for "wrongful termination lawyer San Francisco". Ranked #1 for "EEOC lawyer San Francisco". Client acquisition cost: $270 ‚Üí $150/call. Month 2 revenue: $118,800 (18 new clients). Cumulative ROI: 12x.

Month 3: SEO fully kicked in. Traffic: 4,800 ‚Üí 8,400 visitors/month (75% growth). Organic search: 52% ‚Üí 67% of traffic. Intake calls: 33 ‚Üí 48/month (45% growth). Google ranking: #3 for "wrongful termination lawyer San Francisco", #2 for "severance negotiation San Francisco", #1 for "employment law FAQ". Featured snippet: "How long do I have to file EEOC claim?" (direct answer). Client acquisition cost: $150 ‚Üí $135/call (10% reduction). Month 3 revenue: $172,800 (27 new clients). 90-day cumulative revenue: $345,600. Total investment: $3,200. Return: 10,700%.

THE HARD TRUTH: Legal Websites That Fail

1. Credential-Focused Homepages

Problem: "Harvard Law, Magna Cum Laude, 15 years experience" doesn't differentiate. Every lawyer claims credentials.

Result: Clients care: "Have you solved problems like mine?" Generic credentials = no differentiation.

2. Generic Practice Areas Lists

Problem: "Personal Injury, Criminal Defense, Family Law" tells nothing. No outcomes, no wins.

Result: Describe outcomes: "Won $2.3M settlement." Generic = no proof of competence.

3. Hard-to-Find Contact Forms

Problem: Legal sites bury contact info behind clicks. People in crisis need help NOW.

Result: Phone number and form should be visible above the fold on every page. Hidden = lost clients.

4. No FAQ Content

Problem: Clients search with questions. "How long does divorce take?" "What's the statute of limitations?"

Result: The lawyer who answers these questions gets the call. No FAQ content = invisible to searchers.

5. Stock Photography

Problem: Stock "professional attorney" photo. Feedback: "Who is this guy? Do you even work here?"

Result: Real photos build trust. Stock = fake operation perception = no calls.

6. No Social Proof

Problem: 4.8 Avvo rating, 150 reviews. Website: zero mention. Clients think site looks fake.

Result: Added Avvo badge + featured reviews: 47% increase in consultation requests. Social proof builds trust.

WHICH CHOOSE?

IF YOU NEED SEO & CONTENT MARKETING

Choose 10Web + WordPress

WordPress powers 60% of law firm websites for good reason. Excellent for attorney profiles, case results, and legal blog content. Best for ranking on Google when potential clients search for answers.

IF YOU WANT PREMIUM BOUTIQUE DESIGN

Choose Framer

Modern premium design that stands out from traditional legal templates. Perfect for boutique firms wanting to signal sophistication and expertise. Build in 2-4 hours, PageSpeed 95+.

IF YOU WANT EASIEST PREMIUM SETUP

Choose Squarespace

Beautiful legal templates with attorney profiles and case results display. No technical skills needed. 24/7 support. Premium design builds trust immediately.

IF YOU WANT EXTENSIVE FEATURES

Choose Wix

Consultation booking, client intake forms, app marketplace. Most legal-specific features. Good for firms that need comprehensive functionality.

IF YOU NEED SOMETHING RIGHT NOW

Choose Durable

AI generates site in 30 seconds with attorney bio, services, contact form. Launch today, get clients while you build your practice. Good enough to start.

FAQ: Legal Website Builders

Should I use WordPress or a website builder for my law firm?

Short answer: WordPress (10Web) for SEO and content, Framer/Squarespace for design and ease.

Long answer: Two paths: (1) WordPress via 10Web: Powers 60% of law firm websites. Best for SEO, legal blog content, attorney profiles, case results. Requires WordPress knowledge and maintenance. Best for: firms that need to rank on Google, have content marketing strategy, need plugin ecosystem. (2) Website builders (Framer/Squarespace): Easier setup, beautiful design, faster builds. Best for: boutique firms wanting premium design, solo practitioners with no technical skills, firms that value design over content marketing. Employment law firm case study: rebuilt in 10Web with WordPress, FAQ blog (45 posts), ranked #3 for "wrongful termination lawyer San Francisco", 300% more intake calls. ROI: 10,700% over 90 days.

What should I include on my law firm website?

Short answer: Attorney profiles, case results, practice areas, testimonials, FAQ blog, consultation CTA.

Long answer: Legal websites need six elements: (1) Attorney profiles: Education, bar admissions, practice areas, publications, case highlights. (2) Case results: Verdicts, settlements, wins with specific dollar amounts. (3) Practice areas: Detailed pages explaining your services, not just lists. (4) Client testimonials: Social proof and reviews (Avvo, Google). (5) FAQ blog: Answers to questions clients search ("How long does divorce take?"). (6) Consultation CTA: Phone number and form visible above the fold on every page. Employment law firm added all six: intake calls 12 ‚Üí 48/month (4x increase). Missing any = lost clients.

How do I show case results without violating bar rules?

Short answer: "Results not typical" disclaimer, specific outcomes without guarantees, past results disclaimer.

Long answer: Most state bars allow showing case results with proper disclaimers. Best practices: (1) Use specific outcomes: "$2.4M verdict for construction accident," "$890K settlement for wrongful termination." (2) Add disclaimer: "Results depend on unique facts, not indicative of future outcomes." (3) Never guarantee results: Avoid "We win 90% of cases." (4) Past results disclaimer: "Prior results do not guarantee similar outcomes." Personal injury firm added specific results with disclaimers: Inquiries 9 ‚Üí 27/month (3x increase). Clients want proof you can win. Show results ethically.

Should I offer free consultations on my website?

Short answer: Yes. And make it visible above the fold on every page.

Long answer: Law firm offered free consultation, buried 4 clicks deep. Moved "FREE CONSULTATION" button to header with phone number: 217% more leads in 60 days. Clients in crisis (divorce, injury, arrest) don't browse. They need help NOW. Make it obvious and immediate. Best practice: Header button "FREE CONSULTATION" + phone number. Above the fold on every page. One-click access. No barriers. Law firm saw 217% increase just by making free consultation visible. Hidden consultation = lost clients.

How do I get my law firm website to rank on Google?

Short answer: Create FAQ content answering client questions. Use WordPress (10Web) for best SEO.

Long answer: Clients search with questions, not law firm names. "Can I sue for wrongful termination?" "What's the deadline for EEOC claim?" "How much is my case worth?" The lawyer who answers these questions gets the call. Employment law firm added FAQ blog (45 posts answering client questions). 90 days later: ranked #3 for "wrongful termination lawyer San Francisco", 300% more intake calls. Strategy: (1) Identify client questions. (2) Write detailed FAQ posts. (3) Optimize for local SEO ("wrongful termination lawyer [city]"). (4) Build internal links. (5) Publish consistently. WordPress (10Web) has best SEO for legal content.

Should I include client reviews on my law firm website?

Short answer: Yes. Display Avvo/Google ratings prominently. Social proof builds trust.

Long answer: Law firm: 4.8 Avvo rating, 150 reviews. Website: zero mention. Potential client: "Your site looks fake, where are your reviews?" Added Avvo badge + 3 featured reviews to homepage: 47% increase in consultation requests. Strategy: (1) Display rating badge prominently (Avvo, Google). (2) Feature 3-5 best reviews. (3) Link to full review profile. (4) Keep reviews current. Social proof builds trust faster than claims. Clients want to see what others say. Hide reviews = lose credibility.

Can I build a law firm website myself or should I hire someone?

Short answer: 10Web/Framer yourself (2-8 hours), hire pro for WordPress custom development ($2,000-5,000).

Long answer: Two paths: (1) DIY with website builder (Framer/Squarespace): Beautiful design, easy setup, no coding. Employment law firm rebuilt in 10Web (requires WordPress knowledge), solo practitioner built in Framer in 4 hours. Cost: $15-25/month. Result: Professional site, significant client acquisition. (2) Hire pro for custom WordPress: Custom design, advanced SEO, plugin development. Cost: $2,000-5,000. Best for: large firms with budgets, complex requirements, need ongoing maintenance. Most firms don't need custom. Website builders are sufficient for 90% of law firms.

THE BRUTAL TRUTH

1. Legal Websites Are Answer Engines, Not Brochures

Clients search with questions: "Can I sue for wrongful termination?" The lawyer who answers gets the call. Build FAQ content, not just credential pages.

2. Specific Results Beat Generic Slogans Every Time

"We fight for your rights" = generic = no differentiation. "$2.4M verdict, $890K settlement" = proof = 3x more inquiries. Show outcomes, not slogans.

3. Hidden Contact Forms Lose Clients in Crisis

Clients in crisis need help NOW. Burying contact info 4 clicks deep = lost clients. Phone number and form above the fold = 217% more leads.

4. FAQ Content Ranks You on Google

Employment lawyer added FAQ blog: ranked #3 for "wrongful termination lawyer [city]", 300% more calls. Answer client questions = get found when they search.

5. Outdated Website = Incompetent Lawyer Perception

$500/hour attorney with 2005 website. Prospects: "If he's this outdated, is he behind on case law too?" Rebuilt: client acquisition cost dropped 40%. Design signals competence.

THE WINNER: 10Web + WordPress

WordPress powers 60% of law firm websites for good reason. Excellent for attorney profiles, case results, and legal blog content that ranks on Google.

CHOOSE 10WEB IF:

  • ‚úì Need SEO and content marketing
  • ‚úì Want WordPress power
  • ‚úì Need attorney profiles and case results
  • ‚úì Have WordPress knowledge
  • ‚úì Need plugin ecosystem

CHOOSE FRAMER IF:
